Merged. I took the liberty of doing a bit of a documentation cleanup and a couple of renames, to encourage people to use the new method because it's so much more performant. Specifically:

* `read()` is deprecated
* Added `readTableRows()` as a synonym for `read()` but that is less tempting to use as a "default"
* Renamed `readGenericRecords(SerializableFunction)` to `read(SerializableFunction)` so that by default people feel encouraged to use this one.

Failure seems to be unrelated.

I think splitting it up this way makes a lot of sense. I recently gave a talk at Flink Forward Berlin about the compatibility efforts and I roughly explained the API with those separations but I didn't take the extra further step of thinking how it should be organised in the actual code.
Since this is essentially permanent build breakage, I'm going to merge.
The tests all passed, then timeout occurred while building Python. I've bumped the timeout and will retest, but FYI this is g2g.

This split makes a lot of sense and will reduce confusion down the line. Not to be that guy, but the names "job" and "construction" seem slightly off to me -- I'm thinking more of them as just "model" and "submission"/"management", say.

I've dealt with the above review comments (I'm a bit surprised though I can not find my last comment where I committed to dealing with them, may be I got confused but I'm nearly certain I saw it in this page :-)).

TIKA-2472 will address the missing Metadata#hashCode. 

For the moment ParseResult returns a copy of Metadata to address a non-mutability constraint, I was not sure if overriding all the Metadata setters was the better option or not, as it could introduce the sync issues with future Tika releases adding some new setters; that said - it's probably unlikely to occur soon, so if preferred then I can follow this approach if returning a copy does not look great...

thanks

Fixed python also

I think now is the perfect time to have a naming discussion :-)

**Construction -> ??**

I think "model" is a bit general as a replacement for "construction". It _is_ pretty much what we know as the "Beam programming model". I want to explicitly make clear that there is separately an execution model and a job submission/management model.

I toyed with "pipeline" but opted for something more broad in order to also lump the primitive payloads and standardized payloads into the same artifact. There's no technical reason they need to be in one artifact, but just keeping the artifact count lower because maven is heavy on boilerplate.

Could definitely split into `beam-model-pipeline`, `beam-model-primitives`, `beam-model-standard-transforms`, and `beam-model-standard-fns`.

**Job -> ??**

No strong opinion, but isn't "job" the thing that you are submitting and managing?

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/13529856/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/13529856)

Coverage decreased (-0.008%) to 69.568% when pulling **d538a573ad9fc537ca3188c9307af2748874884f on chamikaramj:sdf_api** into **d6c63396a8d27aaa973b0a403c75d62fb09d9c8e on apache:master**.
To clarify: elements that go into a PCollection must not be _modified_, even though they can be in principle _modifiable_ Java types. So returning a copy is reasonable.

`standard-transforms` would contain, for example, `Combine`?

I'm pretty happy with `job` or `job-management`; submission is to specific (because you can also get out information about running jobs, update, drain, cancel, etc.

I don't know how useful I find `model` as a common prefix, especially when the subpackages are things like 'construction' and 'job'. Something like `org.apache.beam.model.pipeline...` mostly makes sense to me, and I suppose to some extent `...model.execution...` does as well. I don't think `...model.job...` scans particularly well, however. It may be because the job APIs are the only one where there are two top-level systems communicating (at least in how I comprehend the three divisions here)

For "job", I was more expecting something contrasting "execution". I agree that jobs are what we submit and manage, but also what we execute.

For "construction". the split names seem clearer. I don't have a better suggestion and don't feel too strongly about it, but "construction" suggests something active as opposed to passive data structures to me.

Maybe "execution" is the worst of all. Maybe `fn` is still the best for this. Beyond what is currently in `beam_fn_api` it would also have provision and other bits pertinent to setting up a harness and managing it. Certainly its whole point is to invoke UDFs.

@tgroh yes, `standard-transforms` would contain `Combine` and perhaps some more like `Create` and `WriteFiles` (most IOs should manage their own payloads, but this one is in the core SDK). The separation of primitives and standardized transforms is perhaps not critical here.

Also would recommend to create a Coder for ParseResult rather than keeping it Serializable. Java serialization is wicked slow, so this is another benefit that TikaIO can provide for a user. Create an AtomicCoder for it, and register it using something akin to https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/sdks/java/io/amqp/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/amqp/AmqpMessageCoderProviderRegistrar.java

I think this is ready to review. Discussion on the design doc doesn't seem to have produced major disagreements.

The test failure is a Python flake; everything else passed so this is ready for review.
Also how critical is this for 2.2.0, as I would like to get a cut out.
jenkins: retest this please

I would label it _critical_ as I see failures when running queries which have join/aggregation. 

(Test environment: Kafka+MySQL+FlinkRunner)
The lack of automation is an issue for maintainability, but doesn't affect users. So we should merge it for the release and file a ticket against 2.3.0 to find a way to automate it.
We need to explore the world of shading configs and perhaps other resource-manipulating maven plugins so that we aren't making funky hacked versions of properties files for our dependencies.
Agree with an automate configuration (also how to test shaded libraries), this is a workaround that doesn't impact end users, we could look for other options later.
Thanks @wcn3. PTAL
Run Dataflow ValidatesRunner
I'm happy to merge this before the proto shuffle and resolved conflicts. I'm assuming reviews will conclude in that order.
